notes:
1. Definition

The efficiency ($\eta$) of an electric motor is the ratio of the mechanical power output to the electrical power input. It is a measure of how effectively the motor converts electrical energy into useful mechanical work.

$$ \eta = \frac{P_{out}}{P_{in}} = \frac{\text{Mechanical Power Output}}{\text{Electrical Power Input}} $$

Efficiency is a dimensionless number, usually expressed as a percentage.

2. Power and Losses

No motor is 100% efficient. The difference between the input and output power is the power lost within the motor, primarily as heat.

$$ P_{in} = P_{out} + P_{loss} $$

Losses in a motor include:

  • Copper Losses ($I^2R$ losses): Heat dissipated in the stator and rotor windings due to their resistance.
  • Core Losses: Hysteresis and eddy current losses in the iron core.
  • Mechanical Losses: Friction in the bearings and windage (air resistance) on the rotor.

3. Power Formulas

  • Electrical Power Input ($P_{in}$): For a three-phase motor, this is given by $P_{in} = \sqrt{3} V_L I_L \cos(\phi)$, where $V_L$ and $I_L$ are line voltage and current, and $\cos(\phi)$ is the power factor.
  • Mechanical Power Output ($P_{out}$): This is given by the product of the shaft torque ($T$) and the angular velocity ($\omega$).
    • $$ P_{out} = T \omega = \frac{2\pi n T}{60} $$

solvedExamples.question: A three-phase motor draws 10 kW of electrical power while producing 8 kW of mechanical power at its shaft. What is the efficiency of the motor?
solvedExamples.explanation: Efficiency is the ratio of power out to power in: $\eta = P_{out} / P_{in} = 8 \text{ kW} / 10 \text{ kW} = 0.8$. As a percentage, this is 80%.

solvedExamples.question: A motor with an efficiency of 90% has a mechanical power output of 18 kW. How much electrical power does it consume?
solvedExamples.explanation: Rearrange the efficiency formula to solve for input power: $P_{in} = P_{out} / \eta$. $P_{in} = 18 \text{ kW} / 0.90 = 20$ kW.
